required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Dynamic Change in Accommodation After Wearing Multifocal Soft Contact Lenses for Myopia Control
clinical_study.official_title: Dynamic Change in Accommodation After Wearing Multifocal Soft Contact Lenses for Myopia Control

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York College of Optometry

clinical_study.source: State University of New York College of Optometry

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to report the changes in accommodation, aberrations, and myopia in patients wearing multifocal soft contact lens for various durations.
The study objectives are to:
1. Determine the effects of wearing multifocal soft contact lens on accommodation and aberrations over a 12-month period.
2. Determine the effect of wearing multifocal soft contact lens on myopia over a 12-month period.

primary_outcome.description: Change in axial length over the duration of the study
Change in refractive error over the duration of the study
Accommodation at various distances during the study

secondary_outcome.description: The amount of horizontal phoria (in prism diopter) at near while the subjects wore multifocal soft contact lenses, measured using Modified Thorington

arm_group.description: Subjects wore multifocal soft contact lenses for 12 months.

intervention.description: Myopic subjects wore multifocal soft contact lenses for 12 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age: 8-17 years
- Refractive error: Sphere ≤ -10.00D, Cylinder ≤ 1.00D
- Monocular BCVA 20/25 or better
- No previous CL experience required
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of ocular pathology, binocular vision anomalies, refractive surgery, previous myopia control therapy, pharmaceutical agent known to affect accommodation.

overall_official.affiliation: State University of New York College of Optometry

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: State University of New York College of Optometry
